contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
'''Nursing research''' is research that provides evidence used to support [[nursing practice]]s. Nursing, as an evidence-based area of practice, has been developing since the time of [[Florence Nightingale]] to the present day, where many nurses now work as researchers based in [[universities]] as well as in the [[health care]] setting.
[[Nurse education]] places focus upon the use of [[evidence]] from [[research]] in order to rationalise nursing [[Nursing Interventions Classification|interventions]]. In [[England]] and [[Wales]], courts may determine if a nurse acted [[reasonable|reasonably]] based upon whether their intervention was supported by [[research]].
Nursing research falls largely into two areas:
* [[Quantitative research]] is based in the [[paradigm]] of [[logical positivism]] and is focused upon outcomes for clients that are measurable, generally using [[statistics]]. The dominant [[research methods|research method]] is the [[randomised controlled trial]]. * [[Qualitative research]] is based in the paradigm of [[phenomenology (psychology)|phenomenology]], [[grounded theory]], ethnography and others, and examines the experience of those receiving or delivering the nursing care, focusing, in particular, on the [[Value (personal and cultural)|meaning]] that it holds for the individual. The research methods most commonly used are [[interviews]], [[case studies]], [[focus group]]s and [[ethnography]]
Recently in the [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[action research]] has become increasingly popular in nursing.
==Evidence-based quality improvement practices== In 2008, the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality [[AHRQ]] created the [[AHRQ Health Care Innovations Exchange]] to document and share health care quality improvement programs, including hundreds of profiles featuring nursing innovations.<ref>{{cite news |first = Belinda |last = Ireland |url=http://theevidencedoc.com/news/2013/4/2/free-resources-for-quality-improvement-from-ahrq-innovations-exchange-improve-the-quality-of-your-qi |title=Free Resources for Quality Improvement from AHRQ Innovations Exchange - Improve the Quality of Your QI |date=2013-04-02 |accessdate=2013-08-13}}</ref> Each of the nursing profiles contained in this collection contains an evidence rating that assesses how strong the relationship is between the innovative practice and the results described in the profile.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality |url=https://innovations.ahrq.gov/help/evidence-rating |title=What Is the Evidence Rating? |date=2013-01-23 |accessdate=2013-08-20}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Nursing}} * [[AHRQ Health Care Innovations Exchange]] * [[Evidence-based medicine]] * [[Nursing]] * [[Nursing journal]] * [[Nursing theory]]
==References== <references /> *{{cite book | author=Hamer S. & Collinson G.| title=Achieving Evidence-Based Practice| publisher=Ballière Tindall| year=1999 | isbn=0-7020-2349-3}} *{{cite book | author=Parahoo K.| title=Nursing Research: Principles, Process and Issues| publisher=Macmillan | year=1997 | isbn=0-333-69918-1}}
==External links== *{{Commonscat-inline}}
{{Nursing}}

page.title: Psychiatric and mental health nursing in the United States Army

revision.text:
'''Psychiatric and mental health nurses in the [[United States Army Nurse Corps|U.S. Army Nurse Corps]]''' employing groundbreaking protocols and treatments in psychiatric issues to address the unique challenges that our service men and women face,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.goarmy.com/careers-and-jobs/amedd-categories/nurse-corps-jobs/psychiatric-mental-health-nurse.html|title=Psychiatric/Behavioral Health Nurse Jobs (66C)|website=goarmy.com|access-date=2016-11-08}} {{PD-notice}}</ref> more commonly post-traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injuries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nami.org/Find-Support/Veterans-and-Active-Duty|title=NAMI: National Alliance on Mental Illness {{!}} Veterans & Active Duty|website=www.nami.org|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref> Most people understand that trauma exposure is a popular occupational hazard for military members. Psychiatric screenings, before and during their enlistment, and treatments after being exposed to warfare, death, destruction, and torture have been extremely beneficial for military personnel and their dependents.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pols|first=Hans|last2=Oak|first2=Stephanie|date=2016-11-10|title=WAR & Military Mental Health|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=97|issue=12|pages=2132–2142|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2006.090910|issn=0090-0036|pmc=2089086|pmid=17971561}}</ref>
Psychiatric and mental health nurses treat individuals diagnosed with conditions like schizophrenia, post-traumatic stress disorder, bipolar disorder, and depression. They are also trained in behavioral therapy which allows these nurses to teach patients and their loved ones how to deal with, react to, and overcome challenges that go along with different psychiatric disorders. Nurses in the psychiatric and mental health field can assess, examine, and treat patients with mental illness.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discovernursing.com/specialty/psychiatric-nurse#.WCIATS0rKUk|title=Psychiatric Nurse|website=DiscoverNursing.com {{!}} Campaign for Nursing|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref> Nurses with proper training are able to identify and understand the needs and help-seeking behaviors of military members and, with military cultural competence and knowledge about stress injuries, including psychological damage, they are able to deliver patient-centered care to patients with military culture experiences.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nursingworld.org/MainMenuCategories/ANAMarketplace/ANAPeriodicals/OJIN/TableofContents/Vol-20-2015/No1-Jan-2015/Military-Culture-Implications.html|title=Military Culture Implications for Mental Health and Nursing Care|website=www.nursingworld.org|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> [[File:EmergencyPsychiatryProcess.PNG|thumb|Emergency Psychiatry Process]]
== Duties and responsibilities<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://study.com/articles/Psychiatric_Unit_Nurse_Job_Description_Duties_and_Requirements.html|title=Psychiatric Unit Nurse: Job Description, Duties and Requirements|newspaper=Study.com|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> ==
* Prevention of mental illness through mental health promotion activities, interventions when emotional and mental health problems arise, and stabilization of individuals at their highest level of functioning * Provide specialized care to emotionally distressed individuals both as inpatients and outpatients and provide consultations within the general community * Conduct patient counseling, crisis intervention, medication management, milieu and group therapy, and critical incident stress debriefings (CISD) * Serve as an expert educator, adviser, and consultant on mental health issues to department chiefs and staff as well as the patients and their families * Coordinate outpatient psychiatric care within the behavioral health care service line * Conduct medical research on diseases of military importance * Conduct, supervise and participate in graduate medical education and training of other medical personnel * Facilitating social and emotional needs * Supervising medication schedules * Evaluating patient progress * Maintaining a safe environment
=== Unique duty positions<ref name=":0" /> ===
* Psychiatric Clinical Staff or Head Nurse * Head nurse in an alcohol and drug treatment program * Advanced practice positions such as a Psychiatric and Mental Health Nurse Practitioner * Clinical section chief * Instructor * Program director * Member of medical company combat stress control or medical detachment
=== Requirements === [[File:Join the Army Nurse Corps - poster, 1943.jpg|thumb|"Join the Army Nurse Corps" picture, circa June 1943]]
==== Active duty<ref name=":0" /> ==== * Bachelor's of Science in Nursing degree from an accredited nursing program * Between 21 and 42 years of age * Current, valid and unrestricted nursing license * U.S. citizenship
==== Army reserve<ref name=":0" /> ==== * Minimum of a Bachelor's or associate degree in Nursing or diploma in nursing from an accredited nursing school * At least one year of experience in psychiatric nursing * Between 21 and 42 years of age * Current, valid and unrestricted nursing license * U.S. citizenship or permanent residency
=== Training ===
==== Active duty ==== In the U.S. Army, the case diversity nurses experience in caring for Soldiers and their families far exceeds the medical care environment of the private sector. Army Nurse Corps officers have access to the most sophisticated and up-to-date technology, the opportunity to consult with experts in both the military and private sector, plus exceptional professional growth opportunities, which may include but are not limited to paid continuing education, clinical specialization, and residencies.<ref name=":0" />
==== Army reserve ==== The Army Reserve Nurse Corps begins with the Army Medical Department Basic Officer Leaders Course (BOLC), a three-week program that will expose nurses to the variety of mental and physical challenges they will face as a member of the United States Army's health care team. Candidates learn about the Army's approach to health care firsthand, train with other professionals, and attending lectures, conferences, and demonstrations that cover everything from U.S. Army customs to crisis management. Some candidates even have the opportunity to participate in a hands-on medical simulation of an in-theater field medical unit.
After completing BOLC, nurses will then begin serving with a Reserve unit a minimum of two days each month, and participate in annual training for at least two weeks each year. During this time, duties may include attending professional seminars and military or nursing education courses provided by the U.S. Army as well as the opportunity to work in a wide range of health care environments, whether it be in a modern hospital, working with skilled professionals in a variety of clinical situations or supervising paraprofessionals in a field medical unit.<ref name=":0" />
== Walter Reed National Military Medical Center == [[File:Logo of the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.png|thumb|Walter Reed National Military Medical Center logo]] [[Walter Reed National Military Medical Center|The Walter Reed National Military Medical Cente]]<nowiki/>r, formerly known as the Walter Reed Army Medical Center and was open from May 1909 to August 2011 then realigned with the National Naval Medical Center, is located in Washington, D.C. and serves more than 150,000 active and retired military personnel from all branches, admitting 16,000 patients a year. As a provider of specialized care and a referral center for the North Atlantic Regional Medical Command, WRNMMC offers a broad range of clinical and educational opportunities as well as focusing on integrated patient care, teaching, and research opportunities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.goarmy.com/amedd/health-care/facilities/walter-reed-army-medical-center.html|title=Walter Reed National Military Medical Center - Bethesda, Maryland|website=goarmy.com|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref>
=== Research === Early research began in the 1950s with the electrophysiology of neurons in the visual system provided the groundwork for [[David H. Hubel|Dr. David Hubel's]] 1981 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This standard of excellence has been kept with years of research innovations leading to over multiple patents for scientific contributions and numerous publications in high-impact journals such as [[Science (journal)|Science]], [[Nature (journal)|Nature]], [[the New England Journal of Medicine]], and [[JAMA (journal)|the Journal of the American Medical Association]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://wrair-www.army.mil/ReAndDevelop_MilPsychiatryAndNeuroscienceResearch.aspx|title=WRAIR - Center for Military Psychiatry and Neuroscience|website=wrair-www.army.mil|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref>
==== The United States Army Medical Research Unit - Europe ==== The United States Army Medical Research Unit - Europe (USAMRU-E), a subordinate command of the Walter Reed National Military Center, is currently located in Heidelberg, Germany. USAMRU-E conducts applied psychological research to protect, optimize, and enhance psychological resilience for military members while also studying factors that can impact current stressors on the unit as well as the individual and their family. USAMRU-E focuses on command-directed behavioral health assessments and the development and validation of resilience training for the deployment cycle and the professional military education system. At USAMRU-E, individuals are exposed to a wide range of stressors that can negatively impact their behavioral health and well-being. Approximately 20% of those exposed report significant behavioral health problems upon returning from a combat deployment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wrair-www.army.mil/Subordinate_UsamruE.aspx?id=USE|title=WRAIR - Subordinate Command. USAMRU-E|website=wrair-www.army.mil|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref>
=== The National Capital Consortium Psychiatry Residency Program === The National Capital Consortium (NCC) Psychiatry Residency Program, which began in 1996, is unique and innovative graduate medical education program in psychiatry for military medical professionals. For over sixty years, neuropsychiatry investigators at the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research have worked to understand, prevent, and treat the poorly understood and untreated threats to military members health and performance that just "in their head."<ref name=":2" /> Three military medical institutions, WRNMMC, [[Fort Belvoir Community Hospital]] (FBCH), and the [[Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences]] (USUHS), are involved with this integrated psychiatry residency program while keeping the tradition of excellence in graduate medical education alive. NCC psychiatry residents consistently score among the highest in the nation on standard training examinations and a large number of graduates have gone on to become national and world leaders in psychiatry.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wrnmmc.capmed.mil/ResearchEducation/GME/SitePages/Psychiatry/Residency.aspx|title=The National Capital Consortium Psychiatry Residency Program - Walter Reed National Military Medical Center|website=wrnmmc.capmed.mil|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref>
==== Program overview ==== The National Capital Military Psychiatry Residency is a four-year program designed to prepare military physicians and nurses for the practice of general psychiatry in the military and in community settings upon discharge from the military. The program's mission is to train military physicians and nurses to become effective psychiatrists and psychiatric nurses in the variety of future roles they will fill, from military medical operations to multi-disciplinary mental health settings to primary care and other medical-surgical settings. Those who enroll in the psychiatric residency program apply their techniques of social science and psychiatric research to understand and address the many global and day-to-day pressures of military life affecting "mental health" and "psychological resilience." Military psychiatry, psychotherapy, and psychopharmacology are particularly strong areas of emphasis of the program. Faculty members include nationally known leaders in a number of areas of psychiatry, including psychopharmacology, psychoanalysis, neuropsychiatry, child and adolescent psychiatry, consultation-liaison psychiatry, and military psychiatry.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://wrair-www.army.mil/ReAndDevelop_MilPsycAndNeuro_MilitaryPsychiatry.aspx|title=WRAIR - Military Psychiatry|website=army.mil|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref>
Combined residency training opportunities are also offered by the program. Army residents may apply for a 3+2 child psychiatry fellowship, and if accepted, may complete both general and child and adolescent psychiatry training in a total of five years. There is also a five-year combined internal medicine and psychiatry training program offered by the NCC Psychiatry and Internal Medicine Residency Programs. Graduates of this combined program complete requirements necessary for graduation from both residencies and for board certification in both general psychiatry and internal medicine. They also use traditional methods of individual and small-group interview, standard and specialized psychological tests and surveys, and objective measures such as the rates of suicide, re-enlistment, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), to make wide-ranging assessments of slider and military family health and to recommend changes to organization, training, and leadership.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" />
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:U.S. Army Psychiatric Mental Health Nursing Course}} [[Category:Nursing education]] [[Category:Military psychiatry]] [[Category:Mental health in the United States]] [[Category:Psychiatric nursing]] [[Category:Military medicine in the United States]]

A '''religious delusion''' is any [[delusion]] involving religious themes or subject matter.<ref name="Sims">{{cite document|title=Moses and Monotheism|last=Freud | first= Sigmund | authorlink = Sigmund Freud | year=1939 | url=https://archive.org/details/mosesandmonothei032233mbp}} cited in: {{cite document | title = Is Faith delusion? | last=Sims | first = A. | publisher=[[Royal College of Psychiatrists]] | url=http://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/pdf/is%20faith%20delusion%20andrew%20sims%20editedx.pdf}}{{Verify source|what is this actually citing?|date=February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0010-440X(90)90023-L |title=On defining delusions |year=1990 |last1=Spitzer |first1=Manfred |journal=Comprehensive Psychiatry |volume=31 |issue=5 |pages=377–97 |pmid=2225797}}</ref> Though a small minority of psychologists have characterized all or nearly all religion as delusion,<ref name="Sims"/><ref>{{cite journal |first1=Ryan |last1=McKay |year=2004 |title=Hallucinating God? The Cognitive Neuropsychiatry of Religious Belief and Experience |journal=Evolution and Cognition |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=114–25 |url=http://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid:d6409506-5f22-4b82-bcc4-64f7cf5ad8f6}}</ref> others focus solely on a denial of any spiritual cause of symptoms exhibited by a patient and look for other answers relating to a chemical imbalance in the brain.
==Definition == Individuals experiencing religious delusions are preoccupied with religious subjects that are not within the expected beliefs for an individual's background, including culture, education, and known experiences of religion. These preoccupations are incongruous with the [[mood (psychology)|mood]] of the subject. Falling within the definition also are delusions arising in [[psychotic depression]]; however, these must present within a [[major depressive episode]] and be congruous with mood.<ref>{{cite book | last1=Lieberman | first1=Jeffrey A. | last2=Stroup | first2 = T. Scott | last3=Perkins | first3 = Diana O. | title=The American Psychiatric Publishing Textbook of Schizophrenia | year=2006 | publisher=American Psychiatric Publishing | isbn=9781585626465 | page=199}}</ref>
Researchers in a 2000 study found religious delusions to be unrelated to any specific set of diagnostic criteria, but correlated with demographic criteria, primarily age.<ref name="raja2000">{{cite journal |first1=M. |last1=Raja |first2=A. |last2=Azzoni |first3=L. |last3=Lubich |year=2000 |title=Religious delusion: An observational study of religious delusion in a population of 313 acute psychiatric inpatients |journal=Schweizer Archiv für Neurologie und Psychiatrie |volume=151 |issue=1 |pages=22–9 |url=http://www.sanp.ch/pdf/2000/2000-01/2000-01-058.PDF | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322210939/http://www.sanp.ch/pdf/2000/2000-01/2000-01-058.PDF | archivedate=2012-03-22}}</ref> In a comparative study sampling 313 patients, those with religious delusion were found to be aged older, and had been placed on a drug regime or started a treatment programme at an earlier stage. In the context of [[Medical sign|presentation]], their [[Global Assessment of Functioning|global functioning]] was found to be worse than another group of patients without religious delusions. The first group also scored higher on the [[Scale for the Assessment of Positive Symptoms]] (SAPS),<ref>{{cite document | publisher=Psychiatric [[University Hospital Zurich]] | last=Andreasen | first = Nancy C. | year=2007 |url=http://www.bli.uzh.ch/PDF/saps.pdf |title=SCALE FOR THE ASSESSMENT OF POSITIVE SYMPTOMS | accessdate=2012-01-30}}</ref> had a greater total on the [[Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale]] (BPRS),<ref>{{cite document | publisher=[[The University of Iowa]] | work = Iowa Coalition on Mental Health and Aging | url=http://www.public-health.uiowa.edu/icmha/outreach/documents/BPRS_expanded.PDF | title=Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) | accessdate=2012-01-30}}</ref> and were treated with a higher mean number of [[neuroleptic]] medications of differing types during their hospitalization.<ref name="raja2000"/>
Religious delusion was found in 2007 to strongly correlate with "temporolimbic overactivity".<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/10398560601083118 |title=The Interface Between Religion and Psychosis |year=2007 |last1=Ng |first1=Felicity |author10=The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists |journal=Australasian Psychiatry |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=62–66 | pmid = 17464638}}</ref> This is a condition where irregularities in the brain's [[limbic system]] may present as symptoms of [[paranoid schizophrenia]].<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://schizophreniabulletin.oxfordjournals.org/content/23/3/513.full.pdf | title = The Temporolimbic System Theory of Paranoid Schizophrenia | first = Manuel F. | last = Casanova | journal = [[Schizophrenia Bulletin]] | volume = 23 | number = 3 | year = 1997 | pages = 513–515 | publisher = Oxford University Press | doi=10.1093/schbul/23.3.513}}</ref>
In a 2010 study, Swiss psychiatrists found religious delusions with themes of spiritual persecution by malevolent spirit-entities, control exerted over the person by spirit-entities, delusional experience of sin and guilt, or [[Grandiose delusions|delusions of grandeur]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1521/psyc.2010.73.2.158 |title=Delusions with Religious Content in Patients with Psychosis: How They Interact with Spiritual Coping |year=2010 |last1=Mohr |first1=Sylvia |last2=Borras |first2=Laurence |last3=Betrisey |first3=Carine |last4=Pierre-Yves |first4=Brandt |last5=Gilliéron |first5=Christiane |last6=Huguelet |first6=Philippe |journal=Psychiatry: Interpersonal and Biological Processes |volume=73 |issue=2 |pages=158–172}}</ref>
Religious delusions have generally been found to be less stressful than [[Delusion#Themes|other types of delusion]].<ref name="raja2000" /> A study found adherents to [[new religious movement]]s to have similar delusionary cognition, as rated by the Delusions Inventory, to a psychotic group, although the former reported feeling less distressed by their experiences than the latter.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1348/014466599162683 |title=Delusional ideation in religious and psychotic populations |year=1999 |last1=Peters |first1=Emmanuelle |last2=Day |first2=Samantha |last3=McKenna |first3=Jacqueline |last4=Orbach |first4=Gilli |journal=British Journal of Clinical Psychology |volume=38 |pages=83–96 |pmid=10212739}}</ref>
==History== Behaviours out of the ordinary were traditionally viewed as [[demonic possession]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0500960.htm | archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20050222221921/http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0500960.htm | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2005-02-22 | year=2005 | work=Catholic News Service | accessdate=2012-01-23 | title=Real possession by devil not that common, exorcists say during lesson | last=Wooden | first=Cibndy }}</ref> These episodes, although entirely disavowed by modern psychiatry,<ref>{{cite book| last=Peck | first = M. Scott | title=Glimpses of the Devil: a psychiatrist's personal accounts of possession, exorcism, and redemption | publisher=Simon and Schuster | date=4 Jan 2005 | isbn=0-7432-5467-8}}</ref> are evaluated by clinicians only such that they fall within the safety of a treatment programme.
Earlier{{when|date=March 2015}} propositions that religious shamans were motivated by delusions and that their behaviour resembled that of patients with [[schizophrenia]] were found to be incorrect.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1525/ae.1983.10.3.02a00030 |title=Shamanism and schizophrenia: A state-specific approach to the 'schizophrenia metaphor' of shamanic states |year=1983 |last1=Noll |first1=Richard |journal=American Ethnologist |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=443–459}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=12018978 |year=2002 |last1=Polimeni |first1=J |last2=Reiss |first2=JP |title=How shamanism and group selection may reveal the origins of schizophrenia |volume=58 |issue=3 |pages=244–8 |doi=10.1054/mehy.2001.1504 |journal=Medical Hypotheses}}</ref>
In a 1937 essay, [[Sigmund Freud]] stated that he considered believing in a [[single god]] to be a delusion,<ref name="Sims"/> thus extending his 1907 comment that religion is the indication of obsessional neurosis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freud.org.uk/education/topic/10573/subtopic/40000/ |title=Religion as obsessional neurosis |publisher=[[Freud Museum]] | last=Freud | first = Sigmund | year=1907}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1192/apt.10.4.287 |title=Working with patients with religious beliefs |year=2004 |last1=Dein |first1=S. |journal=Advances in Psychiatric Treatment |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=287–294}}</ref> His thoughts defining "delusion" perhaps crystallized from the notion of the religion formulations of the common man (''circa'' 1927) as "patently infantile, foreign to reality";<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freud.org.uk/education/topic/10573/subtopic/40005/ |title=Religion as a mass delusion |publisher=Freud Museum |last=Freud | first = Sigmund | year=1931}}</ref> around the same year he also stated that religion "comprises a system of wishful illusions together with a disavowal of reality, such as we find in an isolated form nowhere else but amentia, in a state of blissful hallucinatory confusion".<ref>{{cite book| title=The Future of an Illusion|last=Freud | first = Sigmund | year=1927 | isbn=978-0-393-00831-9 | oclc= 20479722}} cited in: {{cite journal |doi=10.1590/S0101-60832007000700013 |title=Religion, spirituality and psychotic disorders |year=2007 |last1=Koenig |first1=Harold G. |journal=Revista de Psiquiatria Clínica |volume=34 |pages=95–104}}</ref>
==Prevalence== Examples from a 295-subject study in [[Lithuania]] showed that the most common religious delusions were being a saint (in women) and being God (in men).<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=18695349 |year=2008 |last1=Rudaleviciene |first1=P |last2=Stompe |first2=T |last3=Narbekovas |first3=A |last4=Raskauskiene |first4=N |last5=Bunevicius |first5=R |title=Are religious delusions related to religiosity in schizophrenia? |volume=44 |issue=7 |pages=529–35 |journal=Medicina}}</ref>
In one study of 193 people who had previously been admitted to hospital and subsequently diagnosed with schizophrenia, 24% were found to have religious delusions.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s001270200005 |title=Religious delusions in patients admitted to hospital with schizophrenia |year=2002 |last1=Siddle |first1=Ronald |last2=Haddock |first2=Gillian |last3=Tarrier |first3=Nicholas |last4=Faragher |first4=E.Brian |journal=Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology |volume=37 |issue=3 |pages=130–8 |pmid=11990010}}</ref>
A 1999 study identified that religious delusions were often present or expressed in persons with [[Forensic psychiatry|forensic]] committal to a psychiatric unit.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/h0087835 |title=Understanding the religious ideation of forensically committed patients |year=1999 |last1=Kunst |first1=Jennifer L. |journal=Psychotherapy: Theory, Research, Practice, Training |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=287–297 | url = http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/pst/36/3/287/}}</ref>
==Clinical examples==
===Biblical=== {{see also|Neuroscience of religion|Psychology of religion|Mental health of Jesus}} Although many researchers have brought evidence for a positive role that religion plays in health, others have shown that religious practices and experiences may be linked to [[mental illness]]es of various kind ([[mood disorders]], [[personality disorders]], [[psychiatric disorders]]). In 2011, a team of [[psychiatrists]], [[Behaviorism|behavioral psychologists]], [[neurologists]] and [[Neuropsychiatry|neuropsychiatrists]] from the [[Harvard Medical School]] published a research which suggested the development of a new diagnostic category of psychiatric disorders related to religious delusion and [[hyperreligiosity]].<ref name="JNCN">{{cite journal |last=Murray |first=Evan D. |last2=Cunningham |first2=Miles G. |last3=Price |first3=Bruce H. |title=The Role of Psychotic Disorders in Religious History Considered |journal=Journal of Neuropsichiatry and Clinical Neurosciences |publisher=[[American Psychiatric Association]] |volume=24 |issue=4 |date=September 2011 |pages=410–426 |doi=10.1176/appi.neuropsych.11090214 |cid= |url=https://neuro.psychiatryonline.org/doi/full/10.1176/appi.neuropsych.11090214 |access-date=March 22, 2018 |issn=1545-7222 }}</ref>
They compared the thought and behavior of the most important figures in the [[Bible]] ([[Abraham]], [[Moses]], [[Jesus Christ]] and [[Paul of Tarsus|Paul]])<ref name="JNCN" /> with patients affected by mental disorders related to the [[Spectrum disorder#Psychosis|psychotic spectrum]] using different clusters of disorders and diagnostic criteria ([[DSM-IV-TR]]),<ref name="JNCN" /> and concluded that these Biblical figures "may have had psychotic symptoms that contributed inspiration for their revelations",<ref name="JNCN" /> such as [[schizophrenia]], [[schizoaffective disorder]], [[Bipolar disorder|manic depression]], [[delusional disorder]], [[Grandiose delusions|delusions of grandeur]], [[Auditory hallucination|auditory]]-[[visual hallucination]]s, [[paranoia]], [[Geschwind syndrome]] (Paul especially) and abnormal experiences associated with [[temporal lobe epilepsy]] (TLE).<ref name="JNCN" />
In 1998–2000 [[Poles|Pole]] Leszek Nowak (born 1962)<ref>Not to be confused with Polish philosopher and lawyer [[Leszek Nowak]] (1943–2009) also from Poznań.</ref> from [[Poznań]] authored a study in which, based on his own history of religious delusions of mission and overvalued ideas, and information communicated in the Gospels, made an attempt at reconstructing Jesus′ psyche<ref>Leszek Nowak, [https://web.archive.org/web/20160514125307/http://www.opracowanie.eu/index_2.htm Prywatna Witryna Internetowa Leszka Nowaka] at [[Internet Archive]] (Polish)</ref> with the view of [[Portraits of the historical Jesus#Apocalyptic prophet|Jesus as apocalyptic prophet]].<ref name=Nowak>Analysis of fragments of the New Testament books for Jesus as apocalyptic prophet: Leszek Nowak, [https://web.archive.org/web/20160523101437/http://www.opracowanie.eu/pomylka_2.htm ″A great mistake and disappointment of early Christianity″] at [[Internet Archive]] (Polish)</ref> He does so in chapters containing, in sequence, an analysis of character traits of the ″savior of mankind″, a description of the possible course of events from the period of Jesus' public activity, a [[Naturalism (philosophy)|naturalistic]] explanation of miracles.
===Historical=== A religious experience of communication from heavenly or divine beings could be interpreted as a test of faith. An example of such is [[Joan of Arc]], ''La Pucelle d'Orléans'',<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=A1NrfO2uFNAC | title = A Still, Small Voice: A Practical Guide on Reporting Revelations | first = Father Benedict J. | last = Groeschel | publisher = Ignatius Press | year = 1993 | pages = 52–53| isbn = 9780898704365 }}</ref> who rallied French forces late in the [[Hundred Years' War]].
[[Daniel Paul Schreber]] is an example of a supposed religious delusion occurring in a developed condition of psychosis.<ref>{{cite book | last=Corveleyn | first=Jozef | chapter=Religious Delusion in Psychosis and Hysteria | title=Changing the Scientific Study of Religion: Beyond Freud? | editor-first=J. A. |editor-last=Belzen | year=2009 | publisher=Springer | isbn=9789048125401}}</ref> Schreber was a successful and highly respected German judge until middle age, when he came to believe that God was turning him into a woman. Two of his three illnesses (1884–1885 and 1893–1902) are described in his book ''Memoirs of My Nervous Illness'' (original German title ''Denkwürdigkeiten eines Nervenkranken''),<ref>{{cite book | last =Schreber | first =Daniel Paul | title =Memoirs of My Nervous Illness | publisher =New York Review of Books, 2000 | year = 1903 | location =New York | isbn = 0-940322-20-X}}</ref> which became an influential book in the history of [[psychiatry]] and [[psychoanalysis]] thanks to its interpretation by [[Sigmund Freud]].<ref #Freud>{{cite book | last =Freud | first =Sigmund | authorlink =Sigmund Freud | last2 =Webber | first2 =Andrew (translator) | last3 =MacCabe | first3 =Colin (contributor) | authorlink3 =Colin MacCabe | title =The Schreber Case | publisher =Penguin Classics Psychology, 2003 | year = 1911 | location =New York | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=iY1917GJxqEC&pg=PR22&lpg=PR22&dq=isbn=0142437425#PPP1,M1 | isbn = 0-14-243742-5}}</ref>
The Harvard Medical School research also focused on [[Social psychology|social models]] of [[psychopathology]],<ref name="JNCN" /> analyzing [[new religious movements]] and charismatic [[Cult|cult leaders]] such as [[David Koresh]], leader of the [[Branch Davidians]],<ref name="JNCN" /> and [[Marshall Applewhite]], founder of the [[Heaven's Gate (religious group)|Heaven's Gate cult]].<ref name="JNCN" /> The researchers concluded that "If David Koresh and Marshall Applewhite are appreciated as having psychotic-spectrum beliefs, then the premise becomes untenable that the diagnosis of psychosis must rigidly rely upon an inability to maintain a social group. A subset of individuals with psychotic symptoms appears able to form intense social bonds and communities despite having an extremely distorted view of reality. The existence of a better socially functioning subset of individuals with psychotic-type symptoms is corroborated by research indicating that psychotic-like experiences, including both bizarre and non-bizarre delusion-like beliefs, are frequently found in the general population. This supports the idea that psychotic symptoms likely lie on a continuum."<ref name="JNCN" />
===Auditory hallucination and crime=== An individual may hear communication from heavenly or divine beings compelling one to [[religious violence|commit acts of violence]]. Some cite the case of the Hebrew patriarch [[Abraham]],<ref>{{cite journal | last=Katz | first=Claire Elise | title=The Voice of God and the Face of the Other: Levinas, Kierkegaard, and Abraham | journal=The Journal of Textual Reasoning | date=2001 | url=http://jtr.lib.virginia.edu/archive/volume10/Katz.html | volume=10 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225214716/http://jtr.lib.virginia.edu/archive/volume10/Katz.html | archivedate=2013-12-25 | df= }}</ref> who was commanded by God to [[Binding of Isaac|sacrifice his son Isaac]]. However, when Abraham was prepared to act on it, God informed him that this was only a test of faith and forbade any human sacrifice.
In contemporary times persons judged to have experienced [[auditory hallucination]] include those hearing voices instructing or motivating them to commit violent acts. These auditory experiences are classified by psychiatry as [[command hallucination]].<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=18477881 |year=2008 |last1=Shawyer |first1=F |last2=MacKinnon |first2=A |last3=Farhall |first3=J |last4=Sims |first4=E |last5=Blaney |first5=S |last6=Yardley |first6=P |last7=Daly |first7=M |last8=Mullen |first8=P |last9=Copolov |first9=D |title=Acting on harmful command hallucinations in psychotic disorders: An integrative approach |volume=196 |issue=5 |pages=390–8 |doi=10.1097/NMD.0b013e318171093b |journal=The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease }}</ref> Persons acting to commit [[murder]] are reported as hearing voices of religious beings such as [[God]],<ref>{{cite news | last=Gaines | first = James | authorlink = James R. Gaines | date=March 9, 1987 | newspaper=[[The People]] | url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20095787,00.html | volume=27 | number=10 | title=Mark Chapman Part III: the Killer Takes His Fall}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | work=United Press International | title=Dad: God told me to kill my son | date=12 February 2009 | url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/02/12/Dad-God-told-me-to-kill-my-son/UPI-71281234475937/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://current.com/news-and-politics/89890038_man-says-he-killed-his-son-because-god-told-him-to.htm | title=Man says he killed his son because God told him to | date=March 15, 2009 | work=Current | archiveurl=https://archive.today/20120717043226/http://current.com/news-and-politics/89890038_man-says-he-killed-his-son-because-god-told-him-to.htm | archivedate=2012-07-17 | deadurl=yes | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title="Allah" Told Him to Kill His Family | first = Kim | last = Vatis | first2 = Jenel | last2 = Nels | date = April 14, 2010 | work=NBC Chicago | url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/Four-Shot-in-Marquette-Park-90819234.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Gamiz, Jr. | first=Manuel | title=Allentown slashing suspect says God commanded him to kill | newspaper=The Morning Call | date=30 November 2010 | url=http://articles.mcall.com/2010-11-30/news/mc-allentown-slashing-god-20101130_1_allentown-woman-lamp-cord-allentown-police}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Puxley | first=Chinta | title='God' told man to kill bus passenger | newspaper=Toronto Star | date=March 4, 2009 | url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2009/03/04/god_told_man_to_kill_bus_passenger.html | publisher=The Canadian Press | accessdate=2012-01-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Coryell | first=Lisa | title=New trial ordered for Morrisville man who says God told him to kill | newspaper=New Jersey Times | date=28 February 2011 | url=http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2011/02/new_trial_ordered_for_morrisvi.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Spoto | first=Maryann | title=Man Who Says God Told Him to Kill Girlfriend Gets New Trial | work=Ethics Daily | url=http://ethicsdaily.com/man-who-says-god-told-him-to-kill-girlfriend-gets-new-trial-cms-17538 | date = March 3, 2011}}</ref> [[angels]],<ref>{{cite news | last=Petrie | first=Andrea | newspaper=The Age | title=Schizophrenic stabbed grandmother to death 'after hearing voice of angel' | accessdate=22 January 2012 | date=22 July 2010 | url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/schizophrenic-stabbed-grandmother-to-death-after-hearing-voice-of-angel-20100722-10mco.html}}</ref> or the [[Devil]].<ref>{{cite web | last=LaCapria | first=K. | work=The Inquisitr News | title=Horrific: Mother kills, eats baby in Texas | accessdate=23 January 2012 | url=http://www.inquisitr.com/30950/horrific-mother-kills-eats-baby-in-texas/ | date=28 July 2009}}</ref>
Within the [[anti-psychiatry]] community, Professor Thomas Szasz critiques the concept of religious auditory hallucination: those who hear the voice of God talking to them are experiencing schizophrenia, while those who talk to God but hear no response are simply [[Prayer|praying]].<ref>{{cite web | work=Citizens Commission on Human Rights International | title=Professor Thomas Szasz on Schizophrenia as a Disease | accessdate=23 January 2012 | url=http://www.cchrint.org/about-us/co-founder-dr-thomas-szasz/quotes-on-schizophrenia-as-a-disease/}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Jerusalem syndrome]] *[[Messiah complex]] *[[Religion and schizophrenia]] *''[[The God Delusion]]''
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
[[File:Portrait of R. M. Murray Wellcome M0005974.jpg|thumb|Robert Milne Murray]] [[File:13 Chester Street, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|13 Chester Street, Edinburgh]] [[File:The grave of Robert Milne Murray, Dean Cemetery, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|The grave of Robert Milne Murray, Dean Cemetery, Edinburgh]] '''Robert Milne Murray''' [[FRSE]] FRCPE FRSSA (6 May 1855 – 14 February 1904) was a Scottish surgeon and medical author. Specialising in gynaecology he ran the Edinburgh Maternity Hospital and Simpson Memorial Hospital, He was the first medical Electrician at the [[Edinburgh Royal Infirmary]] but refused to patent any of the devices which he created and instead openly showed the apparatus to vising European colleagues to be feely copied.<ref name="auto">{{cite journal|title=Robert Milne Murray, M.A.St. And., M.D.Edin., F.R.C.P.E., F.R.S.E|date=27 February 1904|publisher=|journal=British Medical Journal|volume=1|issue=2252|pages=521–522|pmc=2353217}}</ref>
==Life== He was born at [[Fettercairn]] on 6 May 1855 the son of the local schoolmaster.
He studied Science at [[St Andrews University]] graduating MA around 1875. After some time assisting Prof [[Matthew Forster Heddle]] he went to [[Edinburgh University]] to study Medicine graduating MB ChB in 1879. He then became assistant to [[John Halliday Croom]] under whom he gained much knowledge in the field of obstetrics and gynaecology.
In 1886 he began Lecturing in Midwifery and Diseases of Women. He was President of the Gynaecological Society of Edinburgh and Vice President of the British Gynaecological Society. He was Vice President of the [[Royal Scottish Society of the Arts]]. He maintaines a private laboratory at Rutland Square.
In 1888 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were Sir [[Thomas Richard Fraser]], [[Alexander Crum Brown]], Sir [[John Batty Tuke]] and [[William Evans Hoyle]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}}</ref>
His final years were spent at 13 Chester Street in Edinburgh's West End, a mid-terraced Victorian townhouse.<ref>Edinburgh Post Office Directory 1901-2</ref>
He caught pneumonia following a severe chill in November 1902. Despite retiring from active work and spending time in a Mediterranean climate the pneumonia remained. On 14 February 1902 he underwent an operation to adjust his ribs in an attempt to relieve his breathing. He died of a heart attack whilst under the anaesthetic aged only 48.<ref name="auto"/>
He was buried on 18 November in [[Dean Cemetery]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gravestonephotos.com/public/gravedetails.php?grave=74766&scrwidth=796|title=Gravestone Photographs Resource grave details page|first=Charles|last=Sale|website=Gravestonephotos.com|accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref> The grave lies on the northern path of the first north extension, on the edge of the north-west section.
==Family== He was married to Margaret (1857 – 1937) but the couple were unable to have children.
==Publications== *''Chemical Notes and Equations'' (1880) *''Post-Partum Incontinence of Urine'' (1881) *''Cessation of Respiration under Chloroform and its Restoration'' (1885) *''Physiological and Therapeutic Actions of Water at Different Temperatures'' (1886) *''Effects of Compression on the Shape of the Fetal Head'' (1888) *''Treatment of Pelvic Disease by Electricity'' (1890) *''The Axis Traction Forceps'' (1896) *''Deflection and Rotation of the Pregnant Uterus'' (1897) *''Relative Advantages of Forceps and Version'' (1896) *''Spontaneous Rupture of Uterus''
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Murray, Robert Milne}} [[Category:1855 births]] [[Category:1904 deaths]] [[Category:People from Edinburgh]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of St Andrews]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Scottish surgeons]] [[Category:Scottish gynaecologists]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Fellows of the Edinburgh Obstetrical Society]]
{{UK-bio-stub}}

The '''Rohrabacher–Farr amendment''' (also known as the '''Rohrabacher–Blumenauer amendment''') is legislation first introduced by U.S. Rep. [[Maurice Hinchey]] in 2001, prohibiting the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] from spending funds to interfere with the implementation of state [[Medical cannabis in the United States|medical cannabis]] laws. It passed the [[United States House of Representatives|House]] in May 2014 after six previously failed attempts, becoming law in December 2014 as part of an [[omnibus spending bill]]. The passage of the amendment was the first time either chamber of Congress had voted to protect medical cannabis patients, and is viewed as a historic victory for cannabis reform advocates at the federal level.{{cite news|last1=Lopez|first1=German|title=The House just voted to protect medical marijuana patients from federal interference|url=https://www.vox.com/2014/5/30/5763654/the-house-just-voted-to-protect-medical-marijuana-patients-from|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Vox|date=May 30, 2014}} The amendment does not change the legal status of cannabis however, and must be renewed each fiscal year in order to remain in effect.{{cite news|last1=Sullum|first1=Jacob|title=The Federal Ban on Medical Marijuana Was Not Lifted|url=http://reason.com/archives/2016/01/04/the-federal-ban-on-medical-marijuana-was|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Reason|date=January 4, 2016}} ==Legislative history== Initially introduced by Rep. Hinchey in 2001, the amendment was withdrawn before it could be brought to a vote.{{cite news|last1=Angell|first1=Tom|title=Federal Medical Marijuana Amendment Author Dies At 79|url=https://www.marijuanamoment.net/federal-medical-marijuana-amendment-author-dies-79/|accessdate=November 24, 2017|work=Marijuana Moment|date=November 24, 2017}} In 2003, Hinchey joined with Rep. [[Dana Rohrabacher]] to introduce the amendment, leading to a 152–273 defeat the first time the amendment was voted on. The Hinchey–Rohrabacher amendment failed five more times over the next decade, until it passed the House (as the Rohrabacher–Farr amendment) by a 219–189 vote on May 30, 2014, as an attachment to the [[Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2015|Commerce, Justice, and Science Appropriations bill]] for fiscal year 2015.{{cite news|last1=Sherer|first1=Steph|title=First major victory in the fight to end federal interference|url=http://www.safeaccessnow.org/first_major_victory_in_the_fight_to_end_federal_interference|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Americans for Safe Access|date=May 31, 2014}} The amendment was then introduced in the Senate by Sens. [[Rand Paul]] and [[Cory Booker]] on June 18,{{cite news|last1=Ferner|first1=Matt|last2=Reilly|first2=Ryan J.|title=Senate Could Follow House In Blocking DEA From Targeting Medical Marijuana|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/19/rand-paul-medical-marijuana_n_5511734.html|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=The Huffington Post|date=June 19, 2014}} but was not allowed a vote.{{cite news|last1=Piper|first1=Bill|title=A Decade of Hard Work Turns into Historic Marijuana Victory in Congress|url=http://www.drugpolicy.org/blog/decade-hard-work-turns-historic-marijuana-victory-congress|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Drug Policy Alliance|date=December 15, 2014}} In December, however, the amendment was inserted into the $1.1 trillion "cromnibus" spending bill as part of final negotiations,{{cite news|last1=Liszewski|first1=Mike|title=Congress Set to Pass Landmark Medical Marijuana Legislation|url=http://www.safeaccessnow.org/congress_set_to_pass_landmark_medical_marijuana_legislation|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Americans for Safe Access|date=December 10, 2014}} and the bill was signed into law by [[Presidency of Barack Obama|President Obama]] on December 16, 2014.{{cite news|last1=Hermes|first1=Kris|title=Feds Back off Medical Marijuana Enforcement in 32 States and DC|url=http://www.safeaccessnow.org/feds_back_off_medical_marijuana_enforcement_in_32_states_and_dc|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Americans for Safe Access|date=December 29, 2014}} The Rohrabacher–Farr amendment passed the House for a second time on June 3, 2015, by a 242–186 margin.{{cite press release|date=June 4, 2015|title=Rohrabacher Hails Passage of Medical Marijuana Amendment|url=https://rohrabacher.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rohrabacher-hails-passage-of-medical-marijuana-amendment|access-date=December 27, 2016}} It was voted on by members of the Senate for the first time on June 11, 2015, winning approval in a 21–9 [[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations|Senate Appropriations Committee]] vote led by sponsor [[Barbara Mikulski]].{{cite news|last1=Liszewski|first1=Mike|title=Senate Committee Approves Mikulski Medical Marijuana Amendment with Strong Bipartisan Support|url=http://www.safeaccessnow.org/senate_committee_approves_mikulski_medical_marijuana_amendment_with_strong_bipartisan_support|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Americans for Safe Access|date=June 11, 2015}} The amendment remained in the [[Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016|FY 2016 omnibus appropriations bill]] that was signed into law by President Obama on December 18, 2015.{{cite news|last1=Liszewski|first1=Mike|title=Congress Set to Reauthorize the Rohrabacher-Farr Medical Cannabis Amendment|url=http://www.safeaccessnow.org/congress_set_to_reauthorize_the_rohrabacher_farr_medical_cannabis_amendment|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Americans for Safe Access|date=December 16, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Sherer|first1=Steph|title=Congress Extends ‘Ceasefire’ On Medical Marijuana, but Can They Clear the Smoke?|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/steph-sherer/congress-extends-ceasefir_b_8853606.html|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=The Huffington Post|date=December 21, 2015}} The Rohrabacher–Farr amendment was not voted on by the House in 2016, but did pass the Senate Appropriations Committee for a second time on April 21, 2016, by a 21–8 vote.{{cite news|last1=Angell|first1=Tom|title=Senators Vote to Bar DEA From Harassing Medical Marijuana Patients|url=http://www.marijuana.com/blog/news/2016/04/senators-vote-to-bar-dea-from-harassing-medical-marijuana-patients/|accessdate=January 3, 2017|work=marijuana.com|date=April 21, 2016}} The amendment was later renewed in a pair of spending bills signed into law on September 29 and December 10,{{cite news|last1=Phillips|first1=Nick|title=BREAKING: Rohrabacher-Farr Extended Until December|url=https://www.marijuanatimes.org/breaking-rohrabacher-farr-extended-until-december/|accessdate=January 2, 2017|work=The Marijuana Times|date=September 29, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Liszewski|first1=Mike|title=Congress Votes to Extend Rohrabacher-Farr Through April|url=http://www.safeaccessnow.org/congress_votes_to_extend_rohrabacher_farr_through_april|accessdate=January 2, 2017|work=Americans for Safe Access|date=December 12, 2016}} and again for an additional week on April 28, 2017.{{cite news|title=Federal medical cannabis protections extended another week|url=https://mjbizdaily.com/federal-medical-cannabis-protections-extended-another-week/|accessdate=May 8, 2017|work=Marijuana Business Daily|date=April 28, 2017}} On May 5, 2017, the Rohrabacher–Farr amendment was renewed until September 30, 2017, as part of a $1 trillion spending bill signed into law by [[Presidency of Donald Trump|President Trump]]. In regards to the medical cannabis provision, Trump added a [[signing statement]] that read: "Division B, section 537 provides that the Department of Justice may not use any funds to prevent implementation of medical marijuana laws by various States and territories. I will treat this provision consistently with my constitutional responsibility to take care that the laws be faithfully executed."{{cite news|last1=Angell|first1=Tom|title=Trump Might Ignore Congress’s Medical Marijuana Rider|url=https://www.massroots.com/news/trump-might-ignore-congresss-medical-marijuana-rider|accessdate=May 8, 2017|work=MassRoots|date=May 8, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Sullum|first1=Jacob|title=Trump's Medical Marijuana Threat Contradicts the Law and His Own Position|url=http://reason.com/blog/2017/05/08/trumps-medical-marijuana-threat-contradi|accessdate=May 8, 2017|work=Reason|date=May 8, 2017}} Days before the spending bill was signed into law, Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]] wrote to congressional leaders urging that the Rohrabacher–Farr amendment not be renewed.{{cite news|last1=Angell|first1=Tom|title=Exclusive: Sessions Asks Congress To Undo Medical Marijuana Protections|url=https://www.massroots.com/news/exclusive-sessions-asks-congress-to-undo-medical-marijuana-protections|accessdate=June 12, 2017|work=MassRoots|date=June 12, 2017}} On July 27, 2017, the Senate Appropriations Committee approved inclusion of the Rohrabacher–Farr amendment in the CJS appropriations bill for fiscal year 2018, in a [[voice vote]] led by sponsor Sen. [[Patrick Leahy]].{{cite news|last1=Angell|first1=Tom|title=Senators OK State Medical Marijuana Protections, Rejecting Sessions|url=https://www.massroots.com/news/senators-ok-state-medical-marijuana-protections-rejecting-sessions|accessdate=July 27, 2017|work=MassRoots|date=July 27, 2017}} On September 6, however, the [[United States House Committee on Rules|House Committee on Rules]] blocked a vote on the amendment, due to Republican leadership viewing it as too divisive.{{cite news|last1=Labak|first1=Aleta|title=GOP-led House Rules Committee blocks voting on bipartisan marijuana amendments|url=http://www.thecannabist.co/2017/09/06/house-rules-committee-rejects-marijuana-amendments-spending-bill-2/87472/|accessdate=September 10, 2017|work=The Cannabist|date=September 6, 2017}} The amendment was then renewed on September 8 as part of an emergency aid package,{{cite news|last1=Schroyer|first1=John|title=Rohrabacher-Blumenauer Amendment extended until December|url=https://mjbizdaily.com/rohrabacher-blumenauer-amendment-extended-december/|accessdate=September 10, 2017|work=Marijuana Business Daily|date=September 8, 2017}} and again through a series of stopgap spending bills on December 8,{{cite news|last1=Pasquariello|first1=Alex|last2=Wallace|first2=Alicia|title=Federal marijuana protections safe for now with stopgap spending bill|url=http://www.thecannabist.co/2017/12/07/federal-budget-medical-marijuana-rohrabacher-blumenauer/94177/|accessdate=December 8, 2017|work=The Cannabist|date=December 8, 2017}} December 22,{{cite news|last1=Pasquariello|first1=Alex|title=Trump signs stopgap spending bill extending federal medical marijuana protections for a few more weeks|url=http://www.thecannabist.co/2017/12/22/federal-budget-medical-marijuana-rohrabacher-blumenauer-extended/95178/|accessdate=December 22, 2017|work=The Cannabist|date=December 22, 2017}} January 22,{{cite news|last1=Hodes|first1=David|title=Senate Revives Gov’t, and Medical Marijuana Protections, Until Feb. 8|url=https://www.leafly.com/news/politics/senate-revives-govt-and-medical-marijuana-protections-until-feb-8|accessdate=January 22, 2018|work=Leafly|date=January 22, 2018}} and February 9{{cite news|last1=Schroyer|first1=John|title=Federal medical cannabis protection extended again|url=https://mjbizdaily.com/federal-medical-cannabis-protection-extended/|accessdate=February 9, 2018|work=Marijuana Business Daily|date=February 9, 2018}} (briefly expiring on January 20). On March 23, the amendment was renewed as part of an omnibus spending bill, in effect through September 30, 2018.{{cite news|title=Trump signs spending bill that includes medical marijuana protections|url=https://mjbizdaily.com/trump-signs-spending-bill-includes-medical-marijuana-protections/|accessdate=March 23, 2018|work=Marijuana Business Daily|date=March 23, 2018}} On May 17, 2018, the [[United States House Committee on Appropriations|House Appropriations Committee]] approved inclusion of the Rohrabacher–Farr amendment in the CJS appropriations bill for fiscal year 2019, in a voice vote led by sponsor Rep. [[David Joyce (politician)|David Joyce]].{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Jeff|title=Powerful congressional panel puts medical marijuana protections in federal budget|url=https://mjbizdaily.com/powerful-congressional-panel-puts-medical-marijuana-protections-in-federal-budget/|accessdate=May 17, 2018|work=Marijuana Business Daily|date=May 17, 2018}} The Senate Appropriations Committee followed on June 12 by approving a base CJS appropriations bill with the amendment included.{{cite news |title=Medical Marijuana Protections Included in Senate CJS Appropriations Bill |url=https://www.mpp.org/news/press/medical-marijuana-protections-included-in-senate-cjs-appropriations-bill/ |accessdate=June 20, 2018 |work=Marijuana Policy Project |date=June 12, 2018}} The amendment was then renewed through December 7 as part of a short-term spending bill signed on September 28.{{cite news |last1=Sink |first1=Justin |last2=Wasson |first2=Erik |title=Trump Signs Bill Averting Government Shutdown Before Midterms |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-28/trump-signs-bill-averting-pre-election-government-shutdown |accessdate=October 8, 2018 |work=Bloomberg |date=September 28, 2018}} ===House votes=== The Rohrabacher–Farr amendment has been introduced on the House floor nine times. It was initially known as the Hinchey–Rohrabacher amendment until [[Maurice Hinchey|Rep. Hinchey]] retired in January 2013, after which Reps. [[Dana Rohrabacher]] and [[Sam Farr]] took over as lead sponsor and co-sponsor. In January 2017, Rep. Farr retired from Congress, with Rep. [[Earl Blumenauer]] taking over as future lead co-sponsor.{{cite news|last1=Wallace|first1=Alicia|title=44 in Congress support effort to keep DOJ handcuffed in medical cannabis states|url=http://www.thecannabist.co/2017/04/10/doj-medical-cannabis-states-rohrabacher-amendment-letter-congress/76993/|accessdate=May 8, 2017|work=The Cannabist|date=April 10, 2017}} The vote totals for the amendment are as follows: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! scope="col" style="width: 50px;" | Year ! scope="col" style="width: 50px;" | Ayes ! scope="col" style="width: 50px;" | Noes ! scope="col" style="width: 50px;" | Not voting |- | 2001 || – || – || – |- | 2003 || 152 || 273 || 9 |- | 2004 || 148 || 268 || 17 |- | 2005 || 161 || 264 || 8 |- | 2006 || 163 || 259 || 10 |- | 2007 || 165 || 262 || 10 |- | 2012 || 163 || 262 || 6 |- | 2014 || 219 || 189 || 23 |- | 2015 || 242 || 186 || 4 |} The passage of the Rohrabacher–Farr amendment in 2014 was noted for its rare [[bipartisan]] support,{{cite news|last1=Dumain|first1=Emma|title=House Marijuana Votes Earn Backing of Rare Bipartisan Coalition (Video)|url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/home/breaking-down-the-votes-on-the-house-medical-marijuana-amendment|accessdate=January 2, 2017|work=Roll Call|date=May 30, 2014}} garnering the approval of 49 Republicans and 170 Democrats.{{cite web|title=Final Vote Results For Roll Call 258|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2014/roll258.xml|website=house.gov|date=May 30, 2014|accessdate=June 17, 2017}} Among the notable "no" votes was [[Democratic National Committee|DNC]] Chair [[Debbie Wasserman Schultz]], who was the only member of Democratic leadership to vote against it.{{cite news|last1=Ferner|first1=Matt|title=New Ads Target Members Of Congress Who Opposed Medical Marijuana Measure|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/05/congress-medical-marijuana_n_5455377.html|accessdate=January 2, 2017|work=The Huffington Post|date=June 5, 2014}} The medical cannabis advocacy group [[Americans for Safe Access]] subsequently targeted Schultz with a TV ad criticizing her vote against the amendment. The Rohrabacher–Farr amendment passed the House in 2015 with the support of 67 Republicans and 175 Democrats.{{cite web|title=Final Vote Results For Roll Call 283|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2015/roll283.xml|website=house.gov|date=June 3, 2015|accessdate=June 17, 2017}} ==Amendment text== The full text of the 2014 House amendment is as follows:{{cite web|title=Amendment Text: H.Amdt.748 — 113th Congress (2013–2014)|url=https://www.congress.gov/amendment/113th-congress/house-amendment/748/text|website=congress.gov|accessdate=January 4, 2017}}
None of the funds made available in this Act to the Department of Justice may be used, with respect to the States of Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, District of Columbia, Florida, Hawaii, Illinois, Iowa, Kentucky, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, Oregon, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Utah, Vermont, Washington, and Wisconsin, to prevent such States from implementing their own State laws that authorize the use, distribution, possession, or cultivation of medical marijuana.
==Implementation== The Rohrabacher–Farr amendment became law in December 2014, but initially failed to have its intended impact, due to the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] interpreting the amendment in an incorrect manner (as later determined by a pair of court rulings). Contrary to the amendment's popular interpretation, the DOJ argued that only state officials were protected from prosecution, and not private individuals or entities involved in the production or distribution of medical cannabis.{{cite news|last1=Sullum|first1=Jacob|title=The Justice Department's Embarrassing Medical Marijuana Switcheroo|url=http://reason.com/blog/2015/08/06/the-justice-departments-embarrassing-med|accessdate=September 16, 2017|work=Reason|date=August 6, 2015}} Since state officials were not being prosecuted to begin with, the DOJ's position was essentially that the amendment had no effect.{{cite news|last1=Ingraham|first1=Christopher|title=How the Justice Department seems to have misled Congress on medical marijuana|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2015/08/06/the-justice-department-says-it-misled-congress-on-medical-marijuana/|accessdate=September 20, 2017|work=The Washington Post|date=August 6, 2015}} This stance conflicted with the DOJ's earlier position (leading up to the May 2014 vote), when it advised members of Congress that the amendment's protections could actually apply more broadly than intended, to cover [[Recreational drug use|recreational]] cannabis as well (in addition to medical).{{cite news|last1=Angell|first1=Tom|title=Exclusive: Justice Department Admits Misleading Congress on Marijuana Vote|url=https://www.marijuana.com/news/2015/08/exclusive-justice-department-admits-misleading-congress-on-marijuana-vote/|accessdate=September 16, 2017|work=marijuana.com|date=August 5, 2015}} After the amendment's enactment, the Justice Department continued to prosecute medical cannabis providers in accordance with the new interpretation.{{cite news|last1=Zilversmit|first1=Marc|title=Obama’s Iran-Contra – The president is spending money that Congress has explicitly told him he can’t spend|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2016/04/obama_s_medical_marijuana_prosecutions_probably_aren_t_legal.html|accessdate=September 16, 2017|work=Slate|date=April 28, 2016}} These actions consequently drew protests from Rohrabacher and others,{{cite news|last1=Downs|first1=David|title=Congressman blasts San Francisco medical pot prosecutions|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/smellthetruth/2015/02/16/congressman-blasts-san-francisco-medical-pot-prosecutions/|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Smell the Truth|publisher=SFGate|date=February 16, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Sullum|first1=Jacob|title=Is the DOJ Defying Congress by Pursuing Medical Marijuana Cases?|url=https://reason.com/blog/2015/02/17/is-the-doj-defying-congress-by-pursuing|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Reason|date=February 17, 2015}} who charged that both the [[Letter and spirit of the law|letter and the spirit]] of the amendment were being violated.{{citation|title=Reaction / response by Reps. Farr, Rohrabacher and Lee on Harborside Health Center court case|url=http://www.harborsidehealthcenter.com/pdf/Harborside_Statement.pdf|date=February 13, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150315084809/http://www.harborsidehealthcenter.com/pdf/Harborside_Statement.pdf|archive-date=March 15, 2015|dead-url=yes}} The DOJ publicly addressed the matter for the first time in April 2015, when a spokesperson confirmed the much more narrow interpretation of the amendment that was being employed.{{cite news|last1=Downs|first1=David|title=Updated: War on California Medical Marijuana Will Continue, Justice Department Says|url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/LegalizationNation/archives/2015/04/03/war-on-california-medical-marijuana-will-continue-justice-department-says|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Legalization Nation|publisher=East Bay Express|date=April 3, 2015}} In response, both Rohrabacher and Farr strongly denounced the interpretation, and a letter was sent to Attorney General [[Eric Holder]] demanding an end to the prosecutions.{{cite news|last1=Liszewski|first1=Mike|title=Reps. Rohrabacher and Farr Send Letter to DOJ to Cease Federal Prosecutions|url=http://www.safeaccessnow.org/reps_rohrabacher_farr_doj_letter|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Americans for Safe Access|date=April 8, 2015}}{{cite press release|date=April 8, 2015|title=Farr and Rohrabacher tell Attorney General: Stop prosecuting medical marijuana cases|url=http://farr.house.gov/index.php/newsroom/press-releases/1152-farr-and-rohrabacher-tell-attorney-general-stop-prosecuting-medical-marijuana-cases/|access-date=December 27, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161224065734/http://farr.house.gov/index.php/newsroom/press-releases/1152-farr-and-rohrabacher-tell-attorney-general-stop-prosecuting-medical-marijuana-cases/|archive-date=December 24, 2016|dead-url=yes}} A letter was also sent to Inspector General [[Michael E. Horowitz|Michael Horowitz]] in July 2015, seeking a government investigation into the matter.{{cite news|last1=Sullum|first1=Jacob|title=Congressmen Ask DOJ Inspector General to Investigate Continued Harassment of Medical Marijuana Patients and Providers|url=http://reason.com/blog/2015/07/31/congressmen-ask-doj-inspector-general-to|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Reason|date=July 31, 2015}}{{cite press release|date=July 31, 2015|title=Rohrabacher, Farr Call for Probe of DOJ’s Illegal Med Pot Prosecutions|url=https://rohrabacher.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rohrabacher-farr-call-for-probe-of-doj-s-illegal-med-pot-prosecutions|access-date=December 27, 2016}} In October 2015, a court ruling by U.S. District Judge [[Charles R. Breyer|Charles Breyer]] affirmed the meaning of Rohrabacher–Farr as the authors originally intended, providing supporters of the amendment with a key legal victory.{{cite news|last1=Reilly|first1=Molly|title=Medical Marijuana Dispensaries Win Battle Against Federal Crackdown|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/medical-marijuana-ruling_us_56265df9e4b08589ef48fee0|accessdate=June 16, 2017|work=HuffPost|date=October 20, 2015}} Judge Breyer in his decision was especially critical of the DOJ interpretation, stating that it "defies language and logic" and "tortures the plain meaning of the statute", and was "counterintuitive and opportunistic".{{cite news|last1=Ingraham|first1=Christopher|title=Federal court tells the DEA to stop harassing medical marijuana providers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2015/10/20/federal-court-tells-the-dea-to-stop-harassing-medical-marijuana-providers/|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=October 20, 2015}} The ruling lifted an [[injunction]] against a California dispensary, the Marin Alliance for Medical Marijuana, and was considered to set important legal precedent inhibiting future prosecutions.{{cite news|last1=Downs|first1=David|title=Major victory for marijuana dispensary in federal court|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/smellthetruth/2015/10/19/major-victory-for-marijuana-dispensary-in-federal-court/|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Smell the Truth|publisher=SFGate|date=October 19, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Downs|first1=David|title=‘We Won the War!’: Reaction to Landmark Medical Marijuana Ruling|url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/LegalizationNation/archives/2015/10/21/we-won-the-war-reaction-to-landmark-medical-marijuana-ruling|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Legalization Nation|publisher=East Bay Express|date=October 21, 2015}} The Justice Department appealed Breyer's ruling, but in April 2016 it withdrew the appeal.{{cite news|last1=Sullum|first1=Jacob|title=DOJ Accepts Decision Saying It May Not Target State-Legal Medical Marijuana Suppliers|url=http://reason.com/blog/2016/04/14/doj-accepts-ruling-that-says-it-may-not|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Reason|date=April 14, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Feds Finally End 18-Year Fight Against MMJ Pioneer Lynnette Shaw|url=https://www.leafly.com/news/politics/feds-finally-end-18-year-fight-against-mmj-pioneer-lynette-shaw|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Leafly|date=April 13, 2016}} In August 2016, the DOJ interpretation was rejected by the [[Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] as well, in a separate case consolidating the appeals of 10 medical cannabis providers in the states of California and Washington.{{cite news|last1=Ferner|first1=Matt|title=The Largest Federal Appeals Court Tells DOJ To Back Off State-Legal Medical Marijuana|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/medical-marijuana-9th-circuit_us_57b36a31e4b04ff883990337|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=The Huffington Post|date=August 16, 2016}} The unanimous ruling of the three-judge panel is binding on the nine western states of the Ninth Circuit, and is considered likely to hold influence on other circuit courts.{{cite news|last1=Dolan|first1=Maura|title=Feds can't spend money to prosecute people who comply with state medical pot laws, court rules|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-medical-pot-20160816-snap-story.html|accessdate=December 27, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=August 16, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Liszewski|first1=Mike|title=Victory – Rohrabacher-Farr Amendment Continues to Help Medical Marijuana Defendants in Federal Court|url=http://www.safeaccessnow.org/victory_rohrabacher_farr_amendment_continues_to_help_medical_marijuana_defendants_in_federal_court|accessdate=January 4, 2017|work=Americans for Safe Access|date=August 16, 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * 2001: [https://www.congress.gov/amendment/107th-congress/house-amendment/196 Amendment overview] * 2003: [https://www.congress.gov/amendment/108th-congress/house-amendment/297 Amendment overview] | [http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2003/roll420.xml Roll call] * 2004: [https://www.congress.gov/amendment/108th-congress/house-amendment/646 Amendment overview] | [http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2004/roll334.xml Roll call] * 2005: [https://www.congress.gov/amendment/109th-congress/house-amendment/272 Amendment overview] | [http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2005/roll255.xml Roll call] * 2006: [https://www.congress.gov/amendment/113th-congress/house-amendment/748 Amendment overview] | [http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2014/roll258.xml Roll call] * 2015: [https://www.congress.gov/amendment/114th-congress/house-amendment/332 Amendment overview] | [http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2015/roll283.xml Roll call] {{DEFAULTSORT:Rohrabacher-Farr amendment}}
